topics.title: Foundations

concepts.title: What is Data
concepts.definition: Recorded observations or measurements collected for analysis and decision-making.
concepts.plain_english: Information you collect to learn what's happening.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when defining the problem and what you need to measure.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside Population vs Sample.
Often learned alongside Types of Variables.
Often learned alongside Levels of Measurement.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: What is Data.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.title: OpenIntro Statistics (free textbook)
resources.description: Intro statistics textbook with clear intuition and examples.

concepts.title: Population vs Sample
concepts.definition: A population is the full set of units of interest; a sample is a subset used to learn about the population.
concepts.plain_english: You usually measure a part, then infer about the whole.
concepts.when_to_use: Use whenever you generalize from measured data to a broader group.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

links.note: Often learned alongside What is Data.
Often learned alongside Types of Variables.
Often learned alongside Levels of Measurement.

resources.description: Intro statistics textbook with clear intuition and examples.

concepts.title: Types of Variables
concepts.definition: Variables are attributes that vary; common types are categorical (labels) and numerical (quantities).
concepts.plain_english: Some columns are categories, others are numbers.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when choosing summaries, charts, and statistical tests.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Types of Variables.

resources.description: Intro statistics textbook with clear intuition and examples.

concepts.title: Levels of Measurement
concepts.definition: Measurement levels (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio) describe what operations and comparisons are valid for a variable.
concepts.plain_english: It tells you what math makes sense for a column.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to avoid invalid averages or differences (e.g., averaging IDs).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Discrete vs Continuous Data
concepts.definition: Discrete data takes countable values; continuous data can take any value within a range.
concepts.plain_english: Counts vs measurements on a scale.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when selecting distributions and modeling choices.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Structured vs Unstructured Data
concepts.definition: Structured data fits rows/columns; unstructured data includes text, images, audio, and free-form content.
concepts.plain_english: Tables vs messy content like notes or documents.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when planning storage, preprocessing, and analysis tooling.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Ambiguity causes misinterpretation

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.

concepts.title: Observational vs Experimental Data
concepts.definition: Observational data records what happened naturally; experimental data results from deliberate interventions with control.
concepts.plain_english: Watching reality vs running a controlled change.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when deciding how strongly you can claim cause-and-effect.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this concept to frame the analysis correctly.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

topics.description: Core ideas about data, variables, and measurement that come before any statistical method.

topics.title: Descriptive Statistics

concepts.title: Mean
concepts.definition: The arithmetic average: sum of values divided by the number of values.
concepts.plain_english: The typical value if everything were evenly spread.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to summarize central tendency for roughly symmetric numerical data.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Data are numeric and comparable (same units/definition).
concepts.limitations: Not robust to outliers.; Can mislead with skewed distributions.

examples.title: Mean quick example
examples.scenario: You measure 6 cycle times (minutes): [10, 12, 9, 11, 10, 13]. You want a baseline summary.
examples.solution: Compute the statistic, interpret it as a baseline, then reduce variation by standardizing work and removing special causes.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Median
concepts.definition: The middle value when data are ordered (50th percentile).
concepts.plain_english: The 'middle' result, less sensitive to outliers than the mean.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when data are skewed or have outliers.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Data can be meaningfully ordered.
concepts.limitations: Less sensitive to tail changes than the mean.; Harder to use in algebraic modeling.

examples.title: Median quick example
examples.scenario: You measure 6 cycle times (minutes): [10, 12, 9, 11, 10, 13]. You want a baseline summary.
examples.solution: Compute the statistic, interpret it as a baseline, then reduce variation by standardizing work and removing special causes.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Mode
concepts.definition: The most frequent value in a dataset.
concepts.plain_english: The value that shows up the most.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for categorical data or to find common repeated values.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Mode micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Mode.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Range
concepts.definition: Maximum minus minimum value.
concepts.plain_english: How wide the values spread from low to high.
concepts.when_to_use: Use as a quick sense of spread (often alongside more robust measures).
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Range micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Range.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Variance
concepts.definition: Average squared deviation from the mean; the square of standard deviation.
concepts.plain_english: Spread measured in squared units; SD is usually easier to interpret.
concepts.when_to_use: Use in modeling and as a building block for SD and inference.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: segment data to find high-variation groups
warnings: Do not reduce variation by lowering quality or shifting burden downstream
Confirm variation is not mostly case-mix driven

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

formulas.label: Sample variance
formulas.explanation: Average squared deviation from the mean.

examples.title: Variance quick example
examples.scenario: You measure 6 cycle times (minutes): [10, 12, 9, 11, 10, 13]. You want a baseline summary.
examples.solution: Compute the statistic, interpret it as a baseline, then reduce variation by standardizing work and removing special causes.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Standard Deviation
concepts.definition: Square root of variance; typical distance of values from the mean.
concepts.plain_english: How consistent results are around the average.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to quantify variability and compare stability across groups/time.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: segment data to find high-variation groups
warnings: Do not reduce variation by lowering quality or shifting burden downstream
Confirm variation is not mostly case-mix driven

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.; Data are numeric; spread is meaningful on this scale.
concepts.limitations: Sensitive to outliers.; Squared deviations may overweight extreme values.

examples.title: Standard Deviation quick example
examples.scenario: You measure 6 cycle times (minutes): [10, 12, 9, 11, 10, 13]. You want a baseline summary.
examples.solution: Compute the statistic, interpret it as a baseline, then reduce variation by standardizing work and removing special causes.

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Interquartile Range (IQR)
concepts.definition: Difference between the 75th and 25th percentiles (Q3 − Q1).
concepts.plain_english: Spread of the middle half of your data.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to describe typical variability and detect outliers robustly.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: segment data to find high-variation groups
warnings: Do not reduce variation by lowering quality or shifting burden downstream
Confirm variation is not mostly case-mix driven

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.title: OpenStax Introductory Statistics 2e
resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Percentiles
concepts.definition: Values below which a given percentage of observations fall (e.g., 90th percentile).
concepts.plain_english: A way to talk about the 'top' or 'bottom' of performance.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for service levels (p90 wait time), tail risk, and benchmarking.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Percentiles.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Quantiles
concepts.definition: Cut points that divide the distribution into equal-sized intervals (quartiles, deciles).
concepts.plain_english: Percentiles grouped into evenly sized buckets.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to summarize distributions and compare groups.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Quantiles.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Z-score
concepts.definition: Number of standard deviations a value is from the mean: (x−μ)/σ.
concepts.plain_english: How unusual a value is compared to typical behavior.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for outlier detection and standardization across scales.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

formulas.label: Z-score
formulas.explanation: How many standard deviations x is from the mean.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Z-score.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Coefficient of Variation (CV)
concepts.definition: Standard deviation divided by mean; a scale-free measure of relative variability.
concepts.plain_english: Variation compared to the average (good for comparing different units).
concepts.when_to_use: Use to compare variability across metrics with different scales.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: segment data to find high-variation groups
warnings: Do not reduce variation by lowering quality or shifting burden downstream
Confirm variation is not mostly case-mix driven

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Coefficient of Variation (CV).
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

resources.description: Free textbook covering descriptive stats through inference.

concepts.title: Median Absolute Deviation (MAD)
concepts.definition: Median of absolute deviations from the median; robust variability measure.
concepts.plain_english: A robust version of SD that ignores extreme outliers.
concepts.when_to_use: Use when outliers or heavy tails make SD misleading.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: segment data to find high-variation groups
warnings: Do not reduce variation by lowering quality or shifting burden downstream

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Skewness
concepts.definition: Measure of asymmetry of a distribution.
concepts.plain_english: Whether data have a long tail to the right or left.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to choose appropriate summaries and transformations.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

concepts.title: Kurtosis
concepts.definition: Measure related to tail heaviness and peak relative to normal distribution.
concepts.plain_english: How extreme the extremes are compared to normal.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to assess tail risk and suitability of normal assumptions.
concepts.improvement_goal: Measure and improve performance using this metric.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Do not optimize one metric while harming outcomes that matter more

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

concepts.title: Outliers
concepts.definition: Observations that are unusually far from the rest of the data (e.g., beyond 1.5×IQR or high |z|).
concepts.plain_english: Extreme values that may signal special causes or data issues.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to detect data errors, special causes, and tail risk; handle with care.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Inconsistent procedures cause inconsistent results

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Outliers.

topics.description: Summarize data using averages, spread, and shape so you can understand what happened.

topics.title: Visualization & EDA

concepts.title: Histogram
concepts.definition: Bar-like plot showing counts (or density) across value bins.
concepts.plain_english: Shows the shape of your data.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to see distribution shape, skew, and outliers.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: choose the right chart for the question

concepts.title: Box Plot
concepts.definition: Plot summarizing median, quartiles, and potential outliers.
concepts.plain_english: A quick view of typical range and extremes.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to compare distributions across groups.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.

concepts.title: Bar Chart
concepts.definition: Chart showing counts or aggregated values for categories.
concepts.plain_english: Compare categories side-by-side.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for categorical comparisons (counts, rates, means).
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.

concepts.title: Line Chart
concepts.definition: Plot of values over an ordered dimension (usually time).
concepts.plain_english: Shows trends over time.
concepts.when_to_use: Use for time-based patterns, seasonality, and changes.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.

concepts.title: Scatter Plot
concepts.definition: Plot of two numerical variables to inspect relationship.
concepts.plain_english: Shows whether two things move together.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to assess association, nonlinearity, and outliers.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.

concepts.title: Density Plot
concepts.definition: Smoothed estimate of the distribution of a variable.
concepts.plain_english: A smoother histogram.
concepts.when_to_use: Use to compare distribution shapes and multi-modality.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.

concepts.title: Pair Plot
concepts.definition: Grid of scatterplots/histograms for multiple variables.
concepts.plain_english: Quickly scans many relationships at once.
concepts.when_to_use: Use during EDA to spot correlations and clusters.
concepts.improvement_goal: Use this visualization to spot patterns and variation.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

levers: choose the right chart for the question
warnings: Bad visuals create bad decisions

concepts.assumptions: Use consistent definitions, units, and measurement processes.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Pair Plot micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Pair Plot.
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

concepts.title: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
concepts.definition: Process of profiling data quality, distributions, relationships, and anomalies before modeling.
concepts.plain_english: The first pass to understand what’s in your data.
concepts.when_to_use: Use at the start of every analysis to avoid garbage-in/garbage-out.
concepts.improvement_goal: Apply this procedure to run analysis consistently.
diagnostic_questions: When does this apply to your question and data?
What decision will you make based on the result?

warnings: Inconsistent procedures cause inconsistent results

concepts.assumptions: Data are defined consistently and represent the population/process of interest.
concepts.limitations: Interpret results in context; poor data quality or bias can mislead conclusions.

examples.title: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) micro example
examples.scenario: You are analyzing a dataset and need to apply: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA).
examples.solution: Use the concept to compute/interpret the result, then decide a next step (clean data, check assumptions, or refine the model).

topics.description: Explore patterns visually and spot issues like outliers, skew, and data quality problems.
